newsitem.title: GERMANY: TENNIS-MUSTER HOBBLES OUT OF STUTTGART OPEN WITH HIP INJURY.
newsitem.headline: TENNIS-MUSTER HOBBLES OUT OF STUTTGART OPEN WITH HIP INJURY.

text.p: Defending champion Thomas Muster limped out of the Stuttgart Open on Wednesday, frustrated by a recurring hip injury.

The Austrian world number three retired from his second-round clash with Mark Woodforde because of pain in his left hip. The Australian had taken a 3-0 lead in the decisive third set when Muster was hobbling about the court.
Afterwards a gloomy Muster said: "I have had this for a few years and it is not getting better. If I knew what to do with it I would be a doctor, not a tennis player.
"It could be a long-term thing but it is too early to say. I'll have to talk over things with the physiotherapist."
Muster aggravated the injury at an invitational event in Hong Kong last week. He had few problems in taking the first set 6-3 against Woodforde but struggled in the second, losing it 6-1.
After lying down on his back during a change-over to get intensive treatment on his left leg at the start of the third set, Muster tried to play on but eventually had to retire after the third game.
"It was okay in the first set but it then got worse and worse from game to game," he said. "It is frustrating. You practice and get ready for a tournament and you can't really do what you want to do.
"I am used to being injured but some injuries you can play with and some you can't."
The $2.2 million Stuttgart event is one of the nine top tournaments on the ATP Tour and has attracted most of the leading 20 players in the world.

The Austrian said he did not know whether he would be fit for next week's high-class Paris indoor event or at next month's world championship in Hanover, the prestigious season-ending tournament formerly known as the Masters.
